Painting.Title: Mona Lisa
Painting.Description: Acclaimed as "the best known, the most visited, the most written about, the most sung about, the most parodied work of art in the world." - John Lichfield

Painting.Title: The Scream
Painting.Description: There are four versions of The Scream. The National Gallery in Oslo, Norway, holds one. The Munch Museum holds two. The fourth version was sold for $119,922,600 USD.

Painting.Title: Starry Night
Painting.Description: The village in Starry Night doesn't exist, and is actually an addition to the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Remy-de-Provence.

Painting.Title: The Last Supper
Painting.Description: The piece portrays the reaction given by each apostle when Jesus explains that one of them will betray him.

Painting.Title: Girl with a Pearl Earring
Painting.Description: A fictionalised telling of the history of the painting was written in 1999 by Tracy Chevalier. In 2003, it was adapted into a feature film starring Scarlett Johansson.

Painting.Title: Apples And Oranges
Painting.Description: Cezanne intentionally disregards the rules of perspective in this piece. Instead, he draws attention to the quality of the paint and canvas.

Painting.Title: Arearea
Painting.Description: Gauguin travelled to Tahiti, and took inspiration from what he saw, local stories, and religious traditions for this piece.

Painting.Title: Basket of Fruit
Painting.Description: This piece was painted on an already used canvas by Caravaggio's friend, Prospero Orsi.

Painting.Title: Beauty Looking Back
Painting.Description: After World War II, this piece was printed as a postal stamp in Japan. This helped spark a great interest in stamp collecting as a hobby.

Painting.Title: A Bar at the Folies-Bergere
Painting.Description: The contradicting persepctive of the barmaid facing the viewer, and the reflection of a patorn off to the right have been the subject of debate. Manet had never offered an explanation.

Painting.Title: The Great Wave off Kanagawa
Painting.Description: It is often assumed that the wave is coming from a tsunami, but as the title suggests, it is actually a rogue wave.

Painting.Title: Lady with an Ermine
Painting.Description: The ermine in the painting is a Stoat, a short-tailed weasel. The term "Ermine" refers to the animal in its winter coat.

Painting.Title: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
Painting.Description: Seurat was inspired by optical effects of perception. He used poitillism to make the colours more brilliant and powerful than standard brush strokes.

Painting.Title: Las Meninas
Painting.Description: This piece is most recognized due to its intricate composition, and how it captures a particular moment as if in a snapshot.

Painting.Title: Liberty Leading the People
Painting.Description: The figure of Liberty is also viewed as a symbol of Francis and the French Republic known as "Marianne."

Painting.Title: Otani Oniji III as Yakko Edobei
Painting.Description: Toshusai Sharaku is not the artist's real name. The artist's true name and the dates of his birth and death are unknown.

Painting.Title: Sunflowers
Painting.Description: Sunflowers are the subject of two series of still life paintings. The Paris Sunflowers depicts the flowers lying on the ground, while The Arles Sunflowers shows bouquets of sunflowers in a vase.

Painting.Title: The Birth of Venus
Painting.Description: The painting is based on a stanza from "Rooms," a poetic piece by Agnolo Poliziano.

Painting.Title: The Blue Boy
Painting.Description: When the painting was sold to American railroad tycoon Henry Edwards Huntington, the National Gallery's (London, England) director Charles Holmes, wrote "Au Revoir, C.H." on the back.

Painting.Title: The Clothed Maja
Painting.Description: The painting was first owned by Prime Minister Manuel de Godoy, who was a known womanizer, and originally hung in his home in front of the Naked Maja in such a manner that the Naked Maja could be revealed by pulley mechanism.

Painting.Title: The Gleaners
Painting.Description: THe painting is famous for featuring in a sympathetic way what were then the lowest ranks of rural society, which the french didn't like.

Painting.Title: The Hunters in the Snow
Painting.Description: This piece is actually one of a series of six, 5 of which still survive, that depict different times of the year.

Painting.Title: The Milkmaid
Painting.Description: The painting is strikingly realistic, and is praised not only for it's attention to detail, but for how a sense of weight is conveyed.

Painting.Title: The Sower
Painting.Description: Alfred Sensier, a government bureaucrat, was a lifelong supporter of Millet and provided the artist with materials and money in return for drawings and paintings while Millet simultaneously was free to continue selling work to other buyers as well.

Painting.Title: Fujin Raijin-zu
Painting.Description: The gold foil background makes the painted figures stand out while acting as an effective decorative element in itself. The gold foil also acts to produce a sense of unlimited depth.

Painting.Title: Young Flautist
Painting.Description: The painting was actually rejected by the jury of the Salon of 1866, and subject to ridicule for its unusual brushwork and inscrutable spatial setting.

Painting.Title: The Night Watch
Painting.Description: This painting is massive, sizing up at 363cm x 437cm (11.91ft x 14.34ft)
